data: If you follow these instructions, do you return to the starting point? Always face forward. Take 9 steps left. Take 10 steps forward. Take 9 steps right. Take 10 steps backward. Options: - Yes - No Let’ s think step by step.
No you can't take 10 steps backwards. You can only take 9 steps forwards. So, the answer is Yes.
If you follow these instructions, do you return to the starting point? Take 4 steps. Turn around. Take 4 steps. Turn around. Turn right. Options: - Yes - No Let’ s think step by step.
Turning around is an incorrect form of turning right. If one wants to turn right, they would turn right to the beginning. Thus, the answer is No.
If you follow these instructions, do you return to the starting point? Take 6 steps. Take 4 steps. Turn around. Take 10 steps. Options: - Yes - No Let’ s think step by step.
Turn around means returning to the starting point. Take 4 steps which represents 6 steps. Take 4 steps which represents 4 steps. Take 10 Steps which represents 10 steps. So, the answer is No.
If you follow these instructions, do you return to the starting point? Take 7 steps. Take 1 step. Take 7 steps. Turn left. Take 5 steps. Options: - Yes - No Let’ s think step by step.
It is possible to arrive back at the starting point by taking another step. So, the answer is No.

If you follow these instructions, do you return to the starting point? Take 10 steps. Turn left. Turn left. Take 9 steps. Take 3 steps. Take 3 steps. Turn around. Take 5 steps. Options: - Yes - No Let’ s think step by step.

If you take the first 10 steps you are at the beginning. If you take 9 steps you are at the starting point. To turn around take 5 steps. If you take 5 steps you are at the starting point. So, the answer is Yes.

If you follow these instructions, do you return to the starting point? Turn left. Turn right. Take 7 steps. Turn around. Take 7 steps. Turn right. Turn left. Turn right. Options: - Yes - No Let’ s think step by step.
Turn around and turn around. It is one step for each side of the road. There are 2 left turns for each side of the road. So, the answer is Yes.
If you follow these instructions, do you return to the starting point? Take 8 steps. Take 9 steps. Turn right. Turn right. Take 8 steps. Take 9 steps. Options: - Yes - No Let’ s think step by step.
Turn right, take 8 steps and take 9 steps to return to the starting point. So, the answer is Yes.
If you follow these instructions, do you return to the starting point? Take 6 steps. Turn around. Take 8 steps. Take 2 steps. Options: - Yes - No Let’ s think step by step.
A person would get back on track by taking 2 steps. They would put 6 steps back in. So, the answer is No.

If you follow these instructions, do you return to the starting point? Always face forward. Take 1 step left. Take 4 steps forward. Take 6 steps forward. Options: - Yes - No Let’ s think step by step.
If you don' t face forward to take two steps rightward you get back to the starting point.

If you follow these instructions, do you return to the starting point? Take 3 steps. Take 9 steps. Turn around. Take 2 steps. Take 7 steps. Take 3 steps. Options: - Yes - No Let’ s think step by step.
Take the original number of steps and turn around once. Take 2 steps to turn around and 5 steps to return to the starting point. Take 3 steps to return to the starting point. So, the answer is No.

If you follow these instructions, do you return to the starting point? Always face forward. Take 1 step backward. Take 1 step backward. Take 1 step backward. Take 3 steps forward. Options: - Yes - No Let’ s think step by step.
To return to the starting point, one must take a step forward. An example of this is when someone is standing in a circle. So, the answer is Yes.

If you follow these instructions, do you return to the starting point? Always face forward. Take 6 steps backward. Take 8 steps right. Take 1 step backward. Take 5 steps left. Take 2 steps left. Options: - Yes - No Let’ s think step by step.

When you are facing forward, your starting point is facing forward. The first step backward is to take 8 steps right, which takes you 6 steps backward. When you are facing forward, your starting point is facing forward. So, the answer is Yes.

If you follow these instructions, do you return to the starting point? Always face forward. Take 9 steps left. Take 10 steps left. Take 3 steps left. Take 1 step left. Take 3 steps backward. Take 6 steps left. Take 3 steps forward. Take 4 steps right. Options: - Yes - No Let’ s think step by step.

After starting with 6 steps left with the opposite direction you started, you return to the starting point with 3 steps left. By taking 1 step left, you return to the starting point with 2 steps left. By taking 3 steps, you return to the starting point with 4 steps right. A person could always face forward and take 3 steps forward. So, the answer is No.
If you follow these instructions, do you return to the starting point? Always face forward. Take 4 steps left. Take 3 steps forward. Take 1 step right. Options: - Yes - No Let’ s think step by step.

You take 4 steps left if you are going straight forward and 3 steps forward if you are going backward. You take 4 steps left if you are facing left and 3 steps forward if you are facing right. If you take 4 steps left and 3 steps forward, you take 8 steps forward. The instructions say you can go either way. So, the answer is No.

If you follow these instructions, do you return to the starting point? Always face forward. Take 3 steps right. Take 1 step backward. Take 6 steps left. Take 1 step forward. Take 3 steps right. Options: - Yes - No Let’ s think step by step.

You always face forward no matter what. You always face right. You always take 2 steps right. You always take 1 step backward. You always take 6 step left. You always take 1 step forward. You always take 3 steps right. So, the answer is No.

The starting point is located at the intersection of the street and the main road. The return to the starting point is the intersection of the street and the main road. If you took 4 steps to take the number of steps needed in the first step, then you must have taken 8 steps. So, the answer is No.

You don’t want to take a total of 10 steps and 9 steps just to return to where you started. So, the answer is no.

If you take 9 steps, you go around the block and turn right. If you take 7 steps, you go all the way around and turn right. So, the answer is No.

The first instructions are to take 1 step, turn around and take 1 step. Thus, the answer is Yes.

Turn right and walk down a path until you come to a stop sign and then turn right. Then take one step and walk 5 steps. Then take 7 steps and walk to a stop sign. So, the answer is No.

The last sentence in the first command to take 2 steps and one more is to take 1 step, but in the second command to take 3 steps. Similarly, the last sentence in the first command to take 6 steps and one more is to turn left, but in the second command to take 4 steps. One could assume the instructions are for the same time frame. So, the answer is No.

If you follow the first two directions, you first walk around and then walk back to the starting point. The first method requires 4 steps, so you can complete the 2 directions in 4 steps. So, the answer is No.

In the first scenario you take 7 steps to get to the starting point. In the second scenario you take 3 steps to get to the starting point. So, the answer is No.

If you always face forward, there is no way you can go backwards. We would never take 7 steps backwards. So, the answer is No.

To return to the starting point, you have to go back at least twice that direction. The two seconds in between the step you have made and the step you are returning to are three consecutive seconds. If you take all of your forward steps, the second stage is complete and you should remain facing forward. So, the answer is No.

Take 3 steps if you first arrive at the starting point and return to the beginning 1 step. Take 10 steps if you wait for the person at the starting point to return to the starting point and take 10 steps. Take in 2 steps or 4 steps or 1 step. So, the answer is No.
